Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that two former Philippine election commission workers were arrested for destroying evidence of cheating in the 2016 polls, when in fact, there is no evidence to support this claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or credible sources provided to back up the assertion that the two individuals were arrested for destroying evidence.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the two individuals mentioned, Nicanor Torreblanca and Walden Libona, are former computer programmers for the Commission on Elections (COMELEC), without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that COMELEC has stated that they do not have employees bearing the names of the alleged memory card thieves.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by the Philippine National Police (PNP) who stated that they had not made any such arrest, suggesting that the claim is false.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting misleading information, such as using a photo from an Associated Press report about suspects arrested for a foiled bombing in Manila in 2016, and falsely linking it to the alleged memory card thieves.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the claim as it is making an exaggerated and unsupported assertion.
